titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs, Office Files of Joseph E. Slater
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, International Affairs, Office Files of Joseph E. Slater FA619
titlestmt.author: Lucas Buresch

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-05-14 00:00:11 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs, Office Files of Joseph E. Slater
did.abstract:
The files from the Office of Joseph E. Slater, cover the years 1957 to 1967, and consist primarily of reports, correspondence, inter-office memoranda, and notes. The material has been arranged into six series. There was no discernible order within the series; therefore, the processor imposed an artificial order on their arrangement.
Material falling into the following categories has been removed and transferred to the appropriate records groups in the Ford Foundation Archives:
-Unpublished staff and consultant reports -Speeches by Mr. Slater and other Ford Foundation staff -Office of Reports (OR) publications -Budget papers
Listings of the staff and consultant reports, speeches, and OR publications that were removed from the papers are appended to this register. The Archives maintains an index (#39) of budget papers.
For additional information regarding Mr. Slater and the International Affairs program, the researcher should consult Slater's oral history.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The office files of Joseph E. Slater are divided into six series:
I. CHRONOLOGICAL FILES
II. GEOGRAPHIC FILES
III. MEETING FILES
IV. ORGANIZATION FILES
V. SUBJECT FILES
VI. TRIP NOTES

Some of the series, or items among particular series, are interrelated. When this is the case, cross references are indicated at the head of the series, and/or are listed after the individual folder listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The office files of Joseph E. Slater span the years 1957 to 1967. During this time, Mr. Slater held various positions in the International Affairs (IA) program, ultimately becoming Program Officer in Charge. The files are comprised of many types of documents totaling 21.5 linear feet: reports, drafts, background papers, strategy papers, requests for grant action, correspondence, memoranda, minutes, and notes. This material stems from Slater's involvement in a wide range of activities within and outside the Foundation: conferences, committees, program reviews, meetings, world-wide travel, and day-to-day Foundation activity. The files are particularly strong with regard to the following topics:

In 1962, Slater served as Study Director of the Special Committee appointed by the Board of Trustees, and its Chairman, John J. McCloy. This committee issued a report, "Directives and Terms of Reference for the 1960's". The working papers of the Committee, drafts of its report, and four volumes of supporting material, which are arranged in a separate collection, are complemented by material in Slater's files.

"Directives and Terms of Reference for the 1960's" reviewed the Foundation's program activities from 1950 to 1961, and recommended a revised set of policies and programs for the decade ahead. The four regions of concern to the IA program were: the United States, the Atlantic community, the Pacific, and the international community. Overall, the goals were twofold: to solidify political, economic, and social foundations within each region, and to develop mediums for the coordination and cooperation of their policies in the international arena. An overriding objective was to reduce global tensions.

The bulk of Slater's files document the actions taken by the IA program as a result of the recommendations made in the Committee's Report. The contents of Slater's files may be enhanced if viewed in connection with the report, its supporting material, and with the working files of the Committee. Slater's files which predate the Report's publication (1957-1961), are largely devoted to U.S foreign economic policy, and Atlantic and European affairs. To this end, they are integral to the later material.

In the early 1960s, the building of an Atlantic partnership was a Foundation priority. The main objective of the partnership was to strengthen and unify the European Community to the point where it could be an equal partner to the United States. Another basic principle was the establishment of links between the developed countries of the "free world" and the developing countries.

The files demonstrate lA's interest in meeting the goals of the Atlantic partnership. They document the support given to European initiatives in economic development and integration, higher education, and to the encouragement of relationships between Western Europe and the developing countries.

The files which cover Europe and the Atlantic partnership are not restricted to an individual series. Slater's trips abroad, inter-Foundation activity, and external conferences and organizations all have a bearing on this topic. Of particular significance is the material related to the following individuals, organizations, and subjects:
Individuals
Organizations
Atlantic Institute (1); European Productivity Agency
Subjects

A cohesive Atlantic community was also important to the East- West relationship. The files contain a variety of documentation with regard to this topic. In the late 1950s, IA began to stimulate international cultural activities as a means of expanding East-West contacts. Slater's notes of his trip to the Soviet Union in 1964 indicate the Foundation's concern for East-West issues. A letter from Zbignew Brzezinski (March 23, 1967) reports on the mood in Europe toward East-West issues, and makes recommendations to the Foundation for programs in this area.
For a more detailed account of the topics having to do with Europe, the Atlantic, and the East-West relationship, consult the individual folder listings, located elsewhere in this register.

In 1958, Slater organized an informal group of businessmen, academicians, and former government officials from outside the Foundation to study foreign economic policy, particularly the role of private enterprise in its implementation. The files of the "Foreign Economic Policy Project" include correspondence, reports, memoranda, agenda material, and minutes. Subsequently, Henry Heald (then President of the Foundation) appointed an ad hoc committee (Shepard Stone, Neil Chamberlain, and John Howard) to examine, on behalf of Foundation interests, the issue of economic cooperation in the foreign arena. Material from Slater's study group was used by this committee. (3)

During Slater's tenure, IA expanded to include the developed countries of the Pacific, particularly Japan; and to a lesser degree Australia. IA activities were designed to bring Japanese institutions into the mainstream of western democratic activity, namely that of the Atlantic partnership. The material generated by Herbert Passin, Foundation consultant on Japan throughout the 1960s, documents the Foundation's activities in Japan during that decade. Also included are a few pieces on the Foundation's involvement in Korea during that time.

Although Latin America is not traditionally one of IA's regional interests, Slater was involved in certain Latin American projects. His files include material from a Foundation study to establish a "House of the Americas" (Casa de las Americas). This study was a building block in the creation of the Center for Inter-American Relations. (See PA67-285) Included in the files are the project's final proposal by Philip Van Slyck, and commentary on the project by Latin American scholars.

Slater worked as a consultant to the late Senator Jacob Javits in the establishment of ADELA - the Atlantic Community Development Group for Latin America (P A63-218). Its goal was to encourage multilateral private investment in Latin America. A long-term goal was the establishment of a Latin American Common Market. Slater's correspondence with Javits regarding Latin American economic integration is included in the files. Former President of Colombia, Alberto Lleras Camargo, was also involved in this project.

From March 13 to 17, 1963, Slater attended a seminar sponsored by the Council on Religion and International Affairs entitled, "Intervention and the American Purpose: Cuba 1962". Top government officials who had been involved in the Cuban Missile Crisis were among those who participated in the discussions. The file from this conference includes Slater's handwritten notes of sessions with Paul Nitze, then Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs; Roger Hilsman, then Director of Intelligence and Research Department of State; and Harlan Cleveland, then Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs. The file also includes a copy of a memorandum from Slater to Stone in which Slater conveys some of the discussion's conclusions with regard to the impact of the crisis on the Atlantic alliance.

In 1962, the Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) received an IA grant (P A62-365), for studies concerning the development of the Atlantic partnership and the challenge presented by Communist China. CFR, in turn, established two projects - The United States and China in World Affairs and Atlantic Policy Studies. These projects were comprised of steering committees and smaller study and discussion groups. Slater's files contain many of the working and background papers used by these committees and study groups, and supplement the material in the grant file, which is on microfilm. As a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, Slater also participated in CFR studies which examined the relationship between science and international relations. These files include material produced by two discussion groups, Science and the National Interest and Science and Foreign Policy.

(Slater's files also document lA's interest in exploring the role of science in world affairs, particularly the impact of scientific development on international relations. These files include drafts of reports by Foundation staff and consultants, inter-office memoranda, and correspondence from individuals in the field.)

During Slater's tenure, the IA program was concerned with strengthening the United Nations. The files include preparatory material for a study done by Lawrence Finkestein on this subject. Some Foundation grants to the Brookings Institution were designated for work in this area. The files contain material on two Brookings' projects: (1) the United Nations Policy Studies Program, a committee on which Slater served, and (2) the strengthening of the United Nations' specialized agencies, notably the U.N.'s Institute for Training and Research.

The Foundation's interest in the field of international communications prompted it to participate in the creation of the International Broadcast Institute (1966-1967). The files contain Slater's correspondence with those closely involved with this project - Louis Cowan, David Webster and Sig Mickelson. There is also correspondence documenting international support and recommendations for the establishment of the institute from individuals associated with the media, as well as from professionals in other fields. The group includes Michel Gordey (Le Monde, France), Aurelio Peccei (Olivetti, Italy), Robert McDonald (Vice President, Foreign Policy Association), George Probst, (Chairman, Broadcasting Foundation of America), William Benton and Maurice Mitchell (Publisher and Chairman, and President, Encyclopedia Britannica). Finally, there are numerous internal and external reports which chronicle the development of the institute.

The IA program supported the study of arms control. The files include correspondence relating to a consultants' report by Eric Stevenson and John Teeple, "Research in Arms Control and Disarmament, 1960-1963". Memoranda and correspondence relating to Ernest Lefever's consultancy work in this field are also included.

There is material that demonstrates the Foundation's interest in the caliber of the United States' public service. Of particular interest, is an 8-page letter from Slater to John McCloy (January 1960), on the importance of strong public leadership. The letter contains possible ways to improve the public service career system.

Citizen Education in World Affairs was an IA study to improve adult knowledge of, and participation in world affairs. The memoranda of James Huntley (staff) and Calvin Nichols (consultant) contain information on the Foundation's support of World Affairs Councils throughout the United States, and of other IA activity to promote world affairs education.

Material from the Foundation's 1962 study, Personnel for Overseas Development, is included. This study examined the qualifications of personnel from the developed world, working in developing countries. Both private and public sector organizations were considered.

The files contain material from IA program reviews that took place in 1966 and 1967. They include strategy papers and memoranda regarding many of the topics already mentioned, for example, the Atlantic community, international economic cooperation, relationships between developed and developing countries, rising young leaders, the United Nations, and international scientific cooperation. Two draft reports, "International Order, International Institutions and the United Nations" and "The United Nations, International Institutions and International Order", contain commentary by Henry Kissinger, then at the Center for International Affairs, Harvard University; and Robert Manning, Editor, The Atlantic Monthly.

The "review" files also contain individual country reports. These include several papers on the People's Republic of China. They demonstrate the Foundation's interest in opening lines of communication with Mainland China. One means was to stimulate contemporary Chinese studies in the United States and abroad. In a memorandum (Nov 8, 1966) to Slater, Kenneth T. Young (the Asia Society) suggested a "Program for Contemporary Chinese Affairs" for the years 1970-1995.

Finally, in addition to the extensive memoranda of James Huntley and Herbert Passin, Slater's files also include grantee-status memoranda by Charles McVicker (IA consultant, 1966-1967) documenting a range of IA interests; and some European trip notes of Stanley Gordon, Richard Catalano, Waldemar Nielson, and Shepard Stone, colleagues in the IA program. Mr. Stone was Director of IA from 1955 to 1965. Stone and Slater collaborated on many projects, and shared a close professional relationship. In addition to his trip notes, Slater's files also contain some of Stone's correspondence and memoranda.(4)
NOTES:

(1) The Atlantic Institute should not be confused with the Atlantic Foundation. The creation of a Foundation never came to fruition. However, the material generated by its proposals are located in these files.
(2) The Young Leaders project was a talent scout system to build a community of potential leaders who embraced the European- Atlantic concept.

(3) Slater's committee was also referred to as the Private Initiative for International Economic Cooperation for Growth and Freedom. The goal of the ad-hoc committee as stated by Heald, was a United States and free world program of economic cooperation for growth and freedom.

(4) See Ford Foundation reports #002804, "Citizen Education in World Affairs: 1) The Foreign Policy Association 2) The World Affairs Councils" and #002581, "Report of Committee on Citizen Education in World Affairs", for more information on this topic.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joseph E. Slater, Program Officer in Charge of the International Affairs (IA) Program from January 1967 until November 1967, also held the following positions:
11/1961-7/1962 Study Director, Special Committee to review Ford Foundation's operations and future policies and programs
During Mr. Slater's tenure at the Foundation, he took several leaves of absence:
1961 Department of State, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Educational and Cultural Affairs
1960-61 Development Loan Fund, Assistant Managing Director
1958-59 The President's Committee to Study the United States Military Assistance Program, Executive Secretary

Before joining the Foundation in 1957, Mr. Slater was Chief Economist at the Creole Petroleum Corporation (Standard Oil Co., N.J.) in Caracas, Venezuela; and Executive Director of the Creole Foundation, also in Caracas. Prior to his work in Venezuela, Mr. Slater held various posts in the United States Government, both in the U.S and abroad.
Mr. Slater was born in Salt Lake City, Utah on August 17, 1922. He graduated with honors from the University of California at Berkeley in 1943 with an A.B. degree in Economics.

Mr. Slater resigned from the Foundation in November 1967. From 1967 to 1972 he was President of the Salk Institute, La Jolla, California; and from 1969 to 1986, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies. In 1986, he assumed the post of Chairman of the John J. McCloy International Center in New York City.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.
Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.

Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

did.unittitle: CHRONOLOGICAL FILES

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: CHRONOLOGICAL FILES and the material within each fie, are arranged in reverse chronological order. The folder titles are also listed in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES I, CHRONOLOGICAL FILES (1957-1967), consists of 7.5linear feet of Slater's outgoing correspondence to persons outside the Foundation and to Foundation staff, his memoranda to the files, as well as copies and drafts of requests for grant action (RGAs). CHRONOLOGICAL FILES are a comprehensive documentation of Slater's activities while at the Foundation. The files covering the months September 1960 to August 1957 also contain some of Slater's incoming correspondence. Additional correspondence between Slater and many of the individuals in the latter group may be found in other series. CHRONOLOGICAL FILES also contain two folders of memoranda documenting Slater's May-June 1959 trip to Europe. These files are best used in conjunction with the additional memoranda in the corresponding TRIP NOTES (Series VI) file. There are no chronological files for the November 1961 to November 1960 period, during which time Slater was on a leave of absence.

did.unittitle: GEOGRAPHIC FILES

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES II, GEOGRAPHIC FILES (1957-1967), consists of 2.25 linear feet of correspondence, memoranda, notes, and drafts of reports. GEOGRAPHIC FILES are divided into three subseries: ASIA PACIFIC, EUROPE/ATLANTIC and LATIN AMERICA. Within each sub series the material is further divided into the following sections: countries, individuals, organizations, and topics. The organizations which are filed in each section are entered by name in the ORGANIZATION FILES (Series IV) folder listings with the appropriate cross reference to Series II. Other cross references are indicated in the folder listings. The GEOGRAHIC FILES are best used in conjunction with the TRIP NOTES (Series VI).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: GEOGRAPHIC FILES are comprised of three subseries: ASIA/PACIFIC, EUROPE/ATLANTIC, and LATIN AMERICA. They are arranged in alphabetical order. Within each subseries the sections are arranged in alphabetical order. The material within each folder is arranged in reverse chronological order.

MEETING FILES

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: MEETING FILES are aranged in alphabetical order by title of the meeting, sponsor of the meeting, the place of the meeting, and meeting dates.
The material within each folder is aranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES III, MEETING FILES (1958-1967), consists of 3 linear feet of correspondence, memoranda, notes, agendas, minutes, and background and meeting papers. This series includes all meetings except those of the Council on Foreign Relations and the International Broadcast Institute which are included in Series IV, ORGANIZATION FILES. Series II is made up of many different types of meetings: conferences, committees, seminars, colloquiums, formal and informal study groups, and briefings. Some were sponsored by the Ford Foundation and held internally, others resulted from Foundation grants and were held under the auspices of the grantees, while others matched Foundation interests and were attended by Mr. Slater in his capacity of staff member of the International Affairs program.

did.unittitle: ORGANIZATION FILES

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: ORGANIZATION FILES are arranged in alphabetical order. Organization files containing diverse material are arranged alphabetically by section. The material within each folder is arranged in reverse chronological order.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For ADELA Investment Company, see: Geographic Files (Series II), Latin America, Organizations; and Asia/Pacific, Organizations. For Asian Broadcasting Union, see: Geographic Files (Series II), Asia/Pacific, Organizations. For Center for Inter-American Relations, see: Geographic Files (Series II), Latin America, Organizations. For Center for Southeast Asian Studies, see: Trip Notes (Series VI), Japan, 1966 July. For European Productivity Agency, see: Geographic Files (Series II), Europe/Atlantic, Organizations. For Graduate Institute of International Studies, Geneva, see: Geographic Files (Series II), Europe/Atlantic, European Free Trade Area. For Maison des Sciences de l'Homme (Center of Human Sciences, Paris) see: Trip Notes (Series VI), Paris, 1964 June. For Overseas Development Institute, see: Geographic Files (Series II), Europe/Atlantic, developing countries; Trip Notes (Series VI), Europe, 1958-1959. For PEP (Political and Economic Planning, London) see: Trip Notes (Series VI), Europe, 1958-1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES IV, ORGANIZATION FILES (1957-1967), consists of 3.75 linear feet of reports, correspondence, memoranda, and notes. These files also include the material generated by the following broad study groups of the Council on Foreign Relations: Atlantic Policy Studies, (Atlantic-related study and discussion groups), The United States and China in World Affairs, U.S. Aid Policies and Programs in Vietnam, Science and Foreign Policy, and Science and the National Interest. Also included is some meeting material of the International Broadcast Institute.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Meeting Files (Series III), The United States and Eastern Europe; The United States and Japan.

SUBJECT FILES

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: SUBJECT FILES are arranged in alphabetical order. Subject fies containing diverse material are arranged alphabetically by section. Office of International Affairs contains six sections, two of which - IA Program Review and OIR Self Study - are arranged in reverse chronological order.
The material within each folder is aranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES V, SUBJECT FILES (1957-1967), consists of 3.75 linear feet of reports, drafts, correspondence, memoranda, and notes. Reports, drafts, internal Foundation memoranda, and individual IA dockets (requests for grant action that were submitted to the Trustees for approval) which relate to program and budget planning of the IA program, are included in the subject files, Office of International Affairs. This subject also includes miscellaneous correspondence between Slater and individuals within and outside the Foundation. The miscellaneous correspondence is arranged alphabetically by individual or by his/her affiliated organization. Office of International Affairs also contains some memoranda of Richard Catalano (staff) and Charles McVicker (consultant). Office of International Affairs: miscellaneous notes, includes a memorandum (20 Mar 1961) by Waldemar Nielson on various IA program activities.

TRIP NOTES

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: TRIP NOTES are aranged in reverse chronological order by the inclusive dates of each trip. Within each trip, the places visited are aranged in alphabetical order. Within each folder, the material is aranged in reverse chronological order.

The trip notes of Richard Catalano, Stanley Gordon, Waldemar Nielson, and Shepard Stone are arranged in alphabetical order at the end of the series. The material within each folder is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: SERIES VI, TRIP NOTES (1957-1967), consists of 1.25 linear feet of itineraries, correspondence, memoranda and notes. This material should be used in conjunction with Series II, GEOGRAHIC FILES. The material from Slater's earlier (1958 and 1959) trips to Europe are the most extensively documented. The trip notes of Richard Catalano, Stanley Gordon, Waldemar Nielson, and Shepard Stone are filed separately at the end of the series.
